user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of spinlock:
```c
static int spinlock(void)
{
	struct metal_spinlock lock = METAL_SPINLOCK_INIT;
	const int threads = 10;
	int value, error;

	error = metal_run(threads, spinlock_thread, &lock);
	if (!error) {
		value = total;
		value -= spinlock_test_count * threads;
		if (value) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "counter mismatch, delta = %d\n",
				  value);
			error = -EINVAL;
		}
	}

	return error;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function spinlock:
#define METAL_SPINLOCK_INIT {ATOMIC_FLAG_INIT}
...
struct metal_spinlock {
	atomic_flag v;
}
...
static void *spinlock_thread(void *arg)
{
	struct metal_spinlock *l = arg;
	int i;

	for (i = 0; i < spinlock_test_count; i++) {
		metal_spinlock_acquire(l);
		total++;
		metal_spinlock_release(l);
	}

	return NULL;
}
...
int metal_run(int threads, metal_thread_t child, void *arg)
{
	pthread_t tids[threads];
	int error, ts_created;

	error = metal_run_noblock(threads, child, arg, tids, &ts_created);

	metal_finish_threads(ts_created, (void *)tids);

	return error;
}
...
int metal_run_noblock(int threads, metal_thread_t child,
		     void *arg, void *tids, int *threads_out)
{
	int error, i;
	pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids;

	if (!tids) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid argument, tids is NULL.\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}

	error = 0;
	for (i = 0; i < threads; i++) {
		error = -pthread_create(&tid_p[i], NULL, child, arg);
		if (error) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to create thread - %s\n",
				  strerror(error));
			break;
		}
	}

	*threads_out = i;
	return error;
}
...
void metal_finish_threads(int threads, void *tids)
{
	int i;
	pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids;

	if (!tids) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid argument, tids is NULL.\n");
		return;
	}

	for (i = 0; i < threads; i++)
		(void)pthread_join(tid_p[i], NULL);
}
...
static unsigned int total = 0
...
static const int spinlock_test_count = 1000
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is assigned to in the provided code fragments. Details:
- spinlock(void): has no parameters.
- spinlock_thread(void *arg): the parameter arg is only read and cast to a local pointer (struct metal_spinlock *l = arg); the function does not assign to arg. Calls to metal_spinlock_acquire/release modify the object pointed to by arg, which is permitted by the rule.
- metal_run(int threads, metal_thread_t child, void *arg): parameters are only read (threads used to size the VLA, child and arg passed to metal_run_noblock). No assignment to any parameter.
- metal_run_noblock(int threads, metal_thread_t child, void *arg, void *tids, int *threads_out): none of the parameters are assigned to. The function writes *threads_out = i, which modifies the object pointed to by the pointer parameter (permitted). The tids pointer is only dereferenced via a local pointer (tid_p), not reassigned.
- metal_finish_threads(int threads, void *tids): parameters are only read; tids is cast to a local pointer and used, not assigned to.
- The metal_log macro and other macros/functions shown do not perform assignments to their function parameter variables in the snippets provided.

Therefore there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the supplied code. If additional code (e.g., implementations of metal_spinlock_acquire/release or other functions) exists, please provide it for review, since a violation could appear there (e.g., assigning to a parameter variable inside a function implementation).
